items.title: A Dissertation upon the Orders of Columns...
items.summary: Author: John Wood the Elder Date: 1750 Description: In 1750 John Wood the Elder published his A Dissertation upon the…
items.content_html:
Author: John Wood the Elder

Date: 1750

Description:

In 1750 John Wood the Elder published his A Dissertation upon the Orders of Columns, and their Appendages; the whole constituting the orders of architecture: interspersed with a brief account of the various kinds of intercolumnation observed by the antients. It is a fascinating exploration of the classical orders of architecture, and their use in buildings throughout history.

In the book, Wood provides a detailed analysis of the three classical orders of architecture: Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian. He examines each order in turn, discussing their origins, key features, and typical uses in buildings. Wood also provides numerous examples of buildings that use each order, from ancient Greek temples to contemporary buildings in his own time.

One of the most interesting aspects of Wood's book is his discussion of the various ways in which the classical orders have been adapted and modified over time. He notes that while the basic principles of the orders have remained the same, architects have often experimented with different proportions, ornamentation, and other details to create new and unique buildings.

It is a valuable resource for anyone interested in the history of architecture, or in the classical orders in particular. His clear and concise writing style, combined with numerous illustrations and examples, make the book accessible and engaging for readers of all levels of expertise.

It can be read below or on Google Books.

items.title: Choir Gaure, Vulgarly Called Stonehenge, on Salisbury Plain
items.summary: Author: John Wood the Elder Date: 1747 Description: In 1740 John Wood the Elder carried out a survey of Stonehenge,…
items.content_html:
Author: John Wood the Elder

Date: 1747

Description:

In 1740 John Wood the Elder carried out a survey of Stonehenge, which he published in 1747 titled Choir Gaure, Vulgarly Called Stonehenge, on Salisbury Plain. 

It can be read below or on Google Books.

items.title: Privacy Policy
items.summary: This privacy policy ("policy") will help you understand how johnwoodtheelder.co.uk ("us", "we", "our") uses and protects the data you provide…
items.content_html:
This privacy policy ("policy") will help you understand how johnwoodtheelder.co.uk ("us", "we", "our") uses and protects the data you provide to us when you visit and use johnwoodtheelder.co.uk ("website", "service").

We reserve the right to change this policy at any given time, of which you will be promptly updated. If you want to make sure that you are up to date with the latest changes, we advise you to frequently visit this page.

 

What User Data We Collect

When you visit the website, we may collect the following data:

  • Your IP address.

  • Your contact information and email address.

  • Other information such as interests and preferences.

  • Data profile regarding your online behavior on our website.

 

Why We Collect Your Data

We are collecting your data for several reasons:

  • To better understand your needs.

  • To improve our services and products.

  • To send you promotional emails containing the information we think you will find

    interesting.

  • To contact you to fill out surveys and participate in other types of market research.

  • To customise our website according to your online behaviour and personal preferences.

     

Safeguarding and Securing the Data

johnwoodtheelder.co.uk is committed to securing your data and keeping it confidential. johnwoodtheelder.co.uk has done all in its power to prevent data theft, unauthorised access, and disclosure by implementing the latest technologies and software, which help us safeguard all the information we collect online.

 

Our Cookie Policy

Once you agree to allow our website to use cookies, you also agree to use the data it collects regarding your online behavior (analyze web traffic, web pages you spend the most time on, and websites you visit).

The data we collect by using cookies is used to customize our website to your needs. After we use the data for statistical analysis, the data is completely removed from our systems.

Please note that cookies don't allow us to gain control of your computer in any way. They are strictly used to monitor which pages you find useful and which you do not so that we can provide a better experience for you.

If you want to disable cookies, you can do it by accessing the settings of your internet browser.

 

Links to Other Websites

Our website contains links that lead to other websites. If you click on these links johnwoodtheelder.co.uk is not held responsible for your data and privacy protection. Visiting those websites is not governed by this privacy policy agreement. Make sure to read the privacy policy documentation of the website you go to from our website.

 

Restricting the Collection of your Personal Data

At some point, you might wish to restrict the use and collection of your personal data. You can achieve this by doing the following:

When you are filling the forms on the website, make sure to check if there is a box which you can leave unchecked, if you don't want to disclose your personal information.

If you have already agreed to share your information with us, feel free to contact us via email and we will be more than happy to change this for you.

johnwoodtheelder.co.uk will not lease, sell or distribute your personal information to any third parties, unless we have your permission. We might do so if the law forces us. Your personal information will be used when we need to send you promotional materials if you agree to this privacy policy.

If you have any queries then please contact admin@johnwoodtheelder.co.uk

items.title: About
items.summary: John Wood the Elder John Wood the Elder This website is a celebration of the life and works of John…
items.content_html:
John Wood the Elder

This website is a celebration of the life and works of John Wood the Elder (1704-1754) and his son John Wood the Younger (1728-1782).

We will highlight the legacy that the Georgian Architects have left us in the Buildings in Bath and beyond. We will also explore their life and printed works.

Father & Son are responsible for the way that the city of Bath looks today. Their buildings include Queen Square, The Circus, The Royal Crescent, North and South Parade etc. all in Bath. The Exchange in Bristol and also in Liverpool.

Each page dedicated to a building will be updated as and when we have more information or further photos… they will feature location maps to highlight where the buildings are or were. The updating of the pages of this website is an ongoing process and a not for profit labour of love.

If you have any information and photos to add to the website, then please use the contact us. We want this to be a complete resource for people to use and explore.

We endeavour to ensure that all content has a link to their source or provides the relevant credit on the site. If any information or photo has been used without seeking the appropriate permission; then please contact us and we will either remove the image or provide appropriate references.

items.title: Ground Radar John Wood’s Ledger Stone
items.summary: 14th November 2022 Last week Bristol University visited St Mary’s Church at Upper Swainswick, the final resting place of John…
items.content_html:
14th November 2022

Last week Bristol University visited St Mary’s Church at Upper Swainswick, the final resting place of John Wood the Elder and his family members.

They carried out ground radar analysis above the ledger stones of John Wood the Elder and one of his daughters to try and find out whether there is a family vault below and whether their are more people interred beneath.

Read more at bathnewseum.com

items.title: Conveyance for 14 The Circus, Bath
items.summary: 20th July 2022 Ancestor Homes has a very interesting article on House History: An in depth look at the 1764…
items.content_html:
20th July 2022

Ancestor Homes has a very interesting article on House History: An in depth look at the 1764 Conveyance for 14 The Circus, Bath.

 

It provides an insight into how John Wood the Elder acquired the land The Circus is built on:

The Conveyance then describes how John Wood acquired the land in the first place. Wood had purchased the land off ‘Thomas Garrard late of the Inner Temple London Esquire/since deceased/and Margaret his wife’ along with Samuel Purlewent, also a Gentleman of Bath, who had died by the time of the Conveyance. The parties had signed a deed dated 1 November 1754 for nine acres of land at a yearly rent of £163 (approximately £20,000 in today’s money).

It goes on to also ensure that the exterior of the buildings that form the The Circus, Bath are to be uniform and adhere to the design:

The Conveyance then goes on to ensure the outside of all premises on the Circus is uniform. No chimneys could be altered without the consent of John Wood and stonework was to be cleansed and tombed so no cracks appeared. The deed also contains a clause about the colour of the woodwork; ‘the whole building may be of one colour and also shall and will paint all of the woodwork in the outside of the said messuage and also the outside street door with a quite white colour’.

items.title: National Trust - ‘Georgian Experience’ Bath Assembly Rooms
items.summary: 3th July 2022 March 2023 sees the National Trust taking over the Bath Assembly Rooms. They have owned them since…
items.content_html:
3th July 2022

March 2023 sees the National Trust taking over the Bath Assembly Rooms. They have owned them since 1931 but have leased it to the North East Somerset Council who have housed the Fashion Museum there.

See the update from The National Trust and their plan for Bath Assembly Rooms.

The Bath Assembly Rooms were designed by John Wood the Younger 1769-1771
